name: Increased PKA Activity Leads to Enhanced Neuronal Signaling
hypothesis_text: We hypothesize that increased protein kinase A (PKA) activity in neurons leads to enhanced synaptic transmission through phosphorylation of AMPA receptors, resulting in improved memory formation and learning capabilities.
biological_context: Protein kinase A is a crucial enzyme in neuronal signaling pathways. It is activated by cAMP and phosphorylates various substrates that contribute to synaptic plasticity and memory formation.
data:
gene,expression_level,phosphorylation_level,functional_impact
PKA catalytic,High,N/A,Enhanced signaling
AMPA receptor,Normal,High,Increased conductance
CREB,Normal,High,Increased transcription
PDE4,Low,Low,Reduced cAMP degradation
Adenylyl cyclase,High,Normal,Increased cAMP production
